qas.question: Who defined mammalian as the crown group mammals?
By Rowe's definition, when did he start to exclude animals?
Which group do marsupials and placentals belong to?
How did Timothy Rowe define Mammalia in the mid 19th century?
What are two examples of the most recent ancestor of the Jurassic period?
In what period did mammals live?
For how long have Juassic fossils been referred to the Mammalia?

plausible_answers.text: the most recent common ancestor of living monotremes (echidnas and platypuses)

qas.question: What is one thing Triassic fossils are shown to consist of according to a 19th century paper?

context: In an influential 1988 paper, <a0_0>Timothy Rowe<a0_0/> defined Mammalia phylogenetically as <b3_0>the crown group mammals<b3_0/>, the clade consisting of <b7_0>the most recent common ancestor of living monotremes <b4_0>(echidnas and platypuses)<b7_0/><b4_0/> and <a2_0>therian mammals<a2_0/> (marsupials and placentals) and all descendants of that ancestor. Since this ancestor lived in <b5_0>the Jurassic period<b5_0/>, Rowe's definition excludes all animals from the earlier <a1_0>Triassic<a1_0/>, despite the fact that Triassic fossils in the Haramiyida have been referred to the Mammalia <b6_0>since the mid-19th century<b6_0/>.
